factoid: The hare sensed frost coming the next morning.
The hare was unable to rest and leaped up.
The pack on leash rushed downhill in full cry after the hare.
The borzois not on leash darted after the hounds and the hare.
The hunt, moving slowly, shouted “Stop!” calling in the hounds.
The borzoi whips, with a cry of “A-tu!”, galloped across the field setting the borzois on the hare.
Ilágin, Nicholas, Natásha, and “Uncle” flew recklessly, seeing only the borzois and the hare.
Ilágin, Nicholas, Natásha, and “Uncle” feared only to lose sight of the chase.
The hare they had started was strong and swift.
When the hare jumped up, he did not run at once.
The hare pricked his ears listening to the shouting and trampling.
The hare took a dozen bounds, not very quickly, letting the borzois gain on him.
The hare chose his direction and realized his danger.
The hare laid back his ears and rushed off headlong.
The hare had been lying in the stubble.
In front of the hare was the autumn sowing where the ground was soft.
The two borzois of the huntsman who had sighted the hare were nearest.
The two borzois of the huntsman were the first to see and pursue the hare.
Ilágin’s red-spotted Erzá passed the two borzois, got within a length, flew at the hare with terrible swiftness aiming at his scut, and rolled over like a ball.
The hare arched his back and bounded off more swiftly.
From behind Erzá rushed the broad-haunched, black-spotted Mílka and began rapidly gaining on the hare.
Nicholas shouted “Miláshka, dear!” in triumph.
Mílka would immediately pounce on the hare, but she overtook him and flew past.
The hare had squatted.
The beautiful Erzá reached the hare again.
Erzá paused near the hare’s scut measuring distance to avoid mistake and seize his hind leg.
Ilágin wailed “Erzá, darling!” in a voice unlike his own.
Erzá did not hearken to Ilágin's appeal.
At the moment Erzá would have seized the hare, the hare moved and darted along the balk between winter rye and stubble.
Erzá and Mílka were abreast, running like a pair of carriage horses.
Erzá and Mílka began to overtake the hare.
The hare could run on the balk more easily than the borzois could overtake him.
A third voice shouted “Rugáy, Rugáyushka! That’s it, come on!”.
Uncle’s red borzoi, straining and curving its back, caught up with the two foremost borzois.
The red borzoi pushed ahead of them regardless of strain, put on speed close to the hare.
The red borzoi knocked the hare off the balk onto the rye field.
The red borzoi again put on speed more viciously, sinking to his knees in the muddy field.
The red borzoi rolled over with the hare, muddying his back.
A ring of borzois surrounded the hare.
Everyone drew up round the crowd of dogs.
The delighted “Uncle” dismounted and cut off a pad, shaking the hare for the blood to drip off.
Uncle glanced round with restless eyes while his arms and legs twitched.
Uncle spoke without knowing whom to or what about.
Uncle said “That’s it, come on! That’s a dog!... There, it has beaten them all, the thousand-ruble as well as the one-ruble borzois. That’s it, come on!”.
Uncle was panting and looking wrathfully around as if abusing someone.
Uncle was as if the borzois were his enemies and had insulted him.
Uncle had at last succeeded in justifying himself.
Uncle said “There are your thousand-ruble ones.... That’s it, come on!...”.
Uncle said “Rugáy, here’s a pad for you!”.
Uncle said “You’ve deserved it, that’s it, come on!”.
Nicholas said “She’d tired herself out, she’d run it down three times by herself.”.
Ilágin’s groom asked “But what is there in running across it like that?”.
